{{For|the mythological figure|Perseides}}

{{For|the Mycenaean royal house|Perseid dynasty}}
The '''Perseids''' ({{pron-en|ËpÉrsiË.É¨dz}} {{USdict|pÃ»râ²Â·sÄÂ·Ä­dz}}) are a prolific [[meteor shower]] associated with the [[comet]] [[109P/Swift-Tuttle|Swift-Tuttle]]. The Perseids are so called because the point they appear to come from, called the [[radiant (meteor shower)|radiant]], lies in the [[constellation]] [[Perseus (constellation)|Perseus]]. Meteor showers occur when [[Earth]] moves through a [[meteor stream]]. The stream in this case is called the Perseid cloud and it stretches along the orbit of the Comet [[Swift-Tuttle]]. The cloud consists of particles ejected by the comet as it passed by the [[Sun]]. Most of the dust in the cloud today is approximately a thousand years old. However, there is also a relatively young filament of dust in the stream that was pulled off the comet in 1862. The rate of meteors originating from this filament is much higher than for the older part of the stream.
The '''Perseids''' ({{pron-en|ËpÉrsiË.É¨dz}} {{USdict|pÃ»râ²Â·sÄÂ·Ä­dz}}) are a prolific [[meteor shower]] associated with the [[comet]] [[109P/Swift-Tuttle|Swift-Tuttle]]. The Perseids are so called because the point they appear to come from, called the [[radiant (meteor shower)|radiant]], lies in the [[constellation]] [[Perseus (constellation)|Perseus]]. Meteor showers occur when [[Earth]] moves through a [[meteor stream]]. The stream in this case is called the Perseid cloud and it stretches along the orbit of the Comet [[Swift-Tuttle]]. The cloud consists of particles ejected by the comet as it passed by the [[Sun]]. Most of the dust in the cloud today is approximately a thousand years old. However, there is also a relatively young filament of dust in the stream that was pulled off the comet in 1862. The rate of meteors originating from this filament is much higher than for the older part of the stream.
